MICS Data Analyses Ainhoa Ugarteche 2025-04-24 Overall Comments This bookdown was created to structure the workflow of my MICS data analyses. It was also thought easily share these analytical steps & results. The goal of these analyses are to assess feasibility of MAIHDA models with the children under 5 data. The first focus is interested in data relating to Pakistan. Unlike in other countries, data in Pakistan was delivered by geographical areas. Four geographical areas are distinguished: Balochistan, Sindh, Punjab & Pakshtukistan. My thought is that there were independent statistical teams who deployed the data collections in such regions. Some variables are available in some regions while other are not. For now, this data discrepancy across regions does not concern our analyses.
Chapter 1 ECDI variables 1.1 Raw configuration Output 1.2 Number of individuals with exploitable information Output 1.3 Desciption of ECDI in each region Output

Chapter 1 ECDI variables Context: Creation of Early Childhood Development Index. The ECDI consists of 4 dimensions: (1)Literacy-numeracy, (2)Physical, (3)Social-emotional, (4)Approaches to learning. In total 10 questions are distributed across these dimensions, making up a 10-item ECDI. The ECDI is a binary variable: (a)Being developmentally on track VS (b)Not being on track ECDI items are coded such that answers to questions are 1: YES & 2: NO. Extra codes are for Dont Know (8) & No response(9). Below I describe the variables associated to each ECDI dimension and the scores (answers) contributing to being developmentally on-track: (1)Literacy-numeracy: Vars: EC6, EC7, EC8 Developmentally on track: Having a score of 1 in at least 2 out of the 3 items. (2)Physical EC9=1 OR EC10=2 (3)Approaches to learning: EC9=1 OR EC10=1 (4)Social-emotional: At least 2 out of the 3 items received these scores: EC13=1 , EC14=2 , EC15=2 In this table we describe, in text format, the answers contributing to being developmentally on track. ![Table: ECDI, Answers Contributing To Being Developmentally On Track]/ImageECDIDevelopmentallyOnTrackScores.png) My data consists of datasets of the 4 regions in Pakistan: Balochistan, Pahktukistan, Punjab, Sindh. All household member data was merged in these datasets. I use UF17 var(completion of children under 5 questionnaire) to select only data relating to children under 5 y.o. #Set wd rm(list=ls()) library(haven) library(gtsummary) library(labelled) library(dplyr) #Load all datasets setwd("D:/ainhoa ugarteche/MICS/Exploratory_20250325") Balo<-readRDS("DATA/Created_Datasets/mBalo.rds") Pahktu<-readRDS("DATA/Created_Datasets/mPahktu.rds") Punjab<-readRDS("DATA/Created_Datasets/mPunjab.rds") Sindh<-readRDS("DATA/Created_Datasets/mSindh.rds") #Create filtered datasets Balo_f<-Balo%>%filter(!is.na(UF17)) Pahktu_f<-Pahktu%>%filter(!is.na(UF17)) Punjab_f<-Punjab%>%filter(!is.na(UF17)) Sindh_f<-Sindh%>%filter(!is.na(UF17)) ECDIvars<-c( #Literacy-Numeracy "EC6", "EC7", "EC8", #Physical "EC9","EC10", #Approaches to learning "EC11", "EC12", #Socio-emotional "EC13","EC14", "EC15") 1.1 Raw configuration Output To describe all ECDI items I use a the tbl_summary function from the gtsummary package. In the table, we note: * Sample sizes in each region * Complete data per item * Number of missing per item #Description table function::::::::::::::::: desc_table<-function(data_f){ data_sum<-data_f%>% tbl_summary( include = all_of(ECDIvars), statistic = list(all_continuous() ~ "{mean} ({sd})", all_categorical()~ "{n} ({p}%)") , digits = all_continuous() ~ 2)%>% bold_labels()%>% #Add n per variable add_n( statistic = "{N_nonmiss}", col_label = "**N**", footnote = FALSE) return(data_sum) } #mkpooprzjo table { font-family: system-ui, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Helvetica, Arial, is the region where there is the larger number of Dont Know responses. 1.2 Number of individuals with exploitable information In this section we are interested in describing the people who have YES or NO information on ECDI items. The function used for this table needs to indicate the type for categorical variables as categorical so that both levels of the binary items are described. #Description table function::::::::::::::::: desc_table<-function(data_f){ data_sum<-data_f%>% tbl_summary( include = all_of(ECDIvars), label= list_labels, type = all_categorical() ~ "categorical", # Show all levels for binary variables statistic = list(all_continuous() ~ "{mean} ({sd})", all_categorical()~ "{n} ({p}%)") , digits = all_continuous() ~ 2)%>% bold_labels()%>% #Add n per variable add_n( statistic = "{N_nonmiss}", col_label = "**N**", footnote = FALSE) return(data_sum) } Balo_sum<-desc_table(Balo_f) Pahktu_sum<-desc_table(Pahktu_f) Punjab_sum<-desc_table(Punjab_f) Sindh_sum<-desc_table(Sindh_f) Output ## Output##### tbl_merge( tbls = list(Balo_sum, Pahktu_sum, Punjab_sum,Sindh_sum), tab_spanner = c("**Balo**", "**Pahktu**","**Punjab**", "**Sindh**") ) #pvsmbcllne table { font-family: system-ui, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif, 'Apple Color Emoji', 'Segoe UI Emoji', 'Segoe UI Symbol', 'Noto Color Emoji'; -webkit-font-smoothing: antialiased; -moz-osx-font-smoothing: grayscale; } 5,994 (60%) 11,038 (69%) 5,236 (67%)     Unknown 14,063 14,420 26,474 10,449 1 n (%) Summary of observations Punjab & Pahktukistan are the regions where children seem to score more developmentally favorable scores. 1.3 Desciption of ECDI in each region Through these code lines I create the ECDI dimensions & the ECDI index. ** Those who are developmentally on track as per the ECDI are those who are developmentally on track in at least 3 out of the 4 dimensions** #CREATING VARIABLES DEVELOPMENTALLY ON TRACK VS NOT #Filter by individuals who have information across all variables filtercreateECDI<-function(data){ data <- data %>% filter(if_all(all_of(ECDIvars), ~ !is.na(.))) #if_all in filter. across in mutate() data <- data %>% mutate( # Domain 1: Literacy-numeracy  at least 2 out of 3 are 1 (YES) literacy_track = rowSums(across(c(EC6, EC7, EC8), ~ . == 1), na.rm = TRUE) >= 2, # Domain 2: Physical  EC9 == 1 OR EC10 == 2 physical_track = case_when(EC9 == 1 | EC10 == 2 ~"TRUE", TRUE~"FALSE"), # Domain 3: Approaches to learning  EC11 == 1 OR EC12 == 1 learning_track = case_when(EC11 == 1 | EC12 == 1 |EC11 == 1 & EC12 == 1 ~ "TRUE", TRUE~"FALSE"), # Domain 4: Social-emotional  at least 2 out of 3 specific conditions socioemotional_track = rowSums(cbind(EC13 == 1, EC14 == 2, EC15 == 2), na.rm = TRUE) >= 2, # Final ECDI: Developmentally on track if ALL 4 domains are TRUE ECDI = rowSums(cbind(socioemotional_track == TRUE, learning_track == "TRUE", physical_track == "TRUE", literacy_track == TRUE), , na.rm = TRUE) >= 3 ) return(data) } Balo_f2<-filtercreateECDI(Balo_f) Pahktu_f2<-filtercreateECDI(Pahktu_f) Punjab_f2<-filtercreateECDI(Punjab_f) Sindh_f2<-filtercreateECDI(Sindh_f) Output #stuutwbgsa table { font-family: system-ui, 7,450 (48%) 3,565 (47%)     TRUE 5,439 (55%) 5,248 (56%) 8,141 (52%) 3,975 (53%) ECDI 9,871 9,383 15,591 7,540     FALSE 6,080 (62%) 4,524 (48%) 6,309 (40%) 4,029 (53%)     TRUE 3,791 (38%) 4,859 (52%) 9,282 (60%) 3,511 (47%) 1 n (%) Summary of observations In general, all regions score low in in literacy-numeracy development score (18%:27%) The physical dimension of development provides equally high scores for all regions (91%:92%). Lower developmental score are generally seen for children in the Balochistan region, especially, & Sindh Region. Based on the ECDI, in the Balochistan region 38% are developmentally on track. In the Sindh region 38%. And in the Pahktu & Punjab regions, 52% & 60%, respectively. The scores that are comparatively low for the Balochistan region, in contrast to other regions, are the literacy dimension (18%) & the learning dimension (64%).
